SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. It is quite acceptable to have someone else do the writing at your dictation.

1. Your full name: Mrs Angelina Robertson
2. Your address: Geriatric Centre Wolseley
3. Date: March 15/63
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): Turtle Mountain, Man.
5. What was your father's name and occupation? Charles Henry Wright, farmer.

9. What were your reasons for coming West?
10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?)
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

With my parents.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

13. What means of transportation did you use?

Plough and horse from Manitoba to Saskatchewan.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)

I can't remember, but my parents told stories of a trip and they ran into on the way.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

We stayed at Carnduff, Sask.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

My father homesteaded about 2 miles west of Carnduff.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

One summer at Nipigon, but where my husband rowed a boat.

Summer of 1912 I spent in Calgary.

Live on three winters on the last thirty in Winnipeg.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came?
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

With my parents.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

Stagecoach from Manitoba to Saskatchewan.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)

I can't remember, but my parents told stories of a trip and they saw into the way.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

We stayed at Barnsfield, Sask.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

My family homesteaded about 2 miles north of Barnsfield.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

One summer at Rippon, but while my husband was away.

Summer of 1912 spent in Calgary.

Two or three winters in the late thirties in Edmonton.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came?
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West, tell when they came and where they settled.

My father came to Manitoba in 1882 at Little Mountain Mew.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

Dr. Lockhart made his drive in his first car out to my father's farm and we were all thrilled and excited. Another thing I well remember was two wagons firing. One burned most of my father's wheat stack and let the fire get out of control past part of the house. Another one started on an agricultural fair day and a new uncle who lived 4 miles from us.

19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommendation it as a place to settle?

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West, tell when they came and where they settled.

My father came to Manitoba in 1882 at Turtle Mountain.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

Dr. Lockhart made his trip on his first trip west to my father's farm and we were all thrilled out to meet him. We were very happy to see him and excited. Another thing I well remember was the raging fires. One burned most of my father's wheat stacks but the farmers who were burning their straw stacks and let the fire get out of control paid part of the loss. Another one started on an agricultural fair day and a new house was destroyed by fire. It was on the way home.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?

The only way of travel was horse and sleigh in winter, and horse and wagon in summer. The extent of our travels was our visits to our relatives. We used to enjoy spending Christmas with my uncle who lived in Idaho.

25. When was the first car used in the community?
   - Around about 1905.

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make?
   - At my 5th birthday, Preston's place on his homestead.

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home?
   - About 4 miles away.

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.)
   - We traded there until the Brandon-Estevan CPR line came through our district in 1891. Our village of Carnouff started and a year later and we closed down.

29. How often did you shop in the early days?
   - Once a week.

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogue? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?
   - About 1904.

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

Yes, a few pioneer homesteaders sold their homes and moved out.

The Village was started in business (one store) and one lumber yard by my husband, who was one of the early homesteaders, until his land and work in Rat Portage O.T. was bought out by Mr. Lockhart. My husband worked on the railroad, but he was captain on a pleasure boat built by him.

35. Did many people move away during the 1920s? Did many return?

Yes, a number of young people went elsewhere & found work. My own two sons went to Calgary and in winter worked in a lumber camp. In summer they worked on farms. My son later returned and now lives in the Carnburn district.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here giving dates wherever possible.

My father was one of the first school trustees and director of Agricultural Fair in pioneer days. I was president of the W.M.S. for two terms and had a class on a Sunday school for years.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district, mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.)

My father was one of the first members of the Oddfellows and Foresters lodges in the district and has been a member of the building committee for years.

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post Offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.) Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name, (2) origin and meaning of the name, (3) date of its adoption, (4) any changes in names since the first name was given, date and reason for change. Give facts of new name as above in (1), (2), (3).

Carnburn was named after one of the first pioneers on homestead by the name of John Earnshaw around 1882 and he was also the first Post Master. When the CPR came through he moved to Carnburn and continued the Post Office. In 1905 when Dr. Lockhart was mayor Carnburn was named a Town.

They are next third generation in Barnsfield district and his parents and his strand brothers pioneer homesteaders in prairie

What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came West?

To me in 1901 when C.P.R. came through, when our village was started and school built and attended school when the first school was built and Paul Francis & Keloraine Tobin farmers no longer had to haul grain to Kelloraine to sell in Cannington, when they ground their flour.
